reviewText: Matthew Bourne's "Swan Lake" will not appeal to some...especially anyone living in the Bible-Thumping Bible Belt of the United States. However, I totally enjoyed Bourne's version of Swan Lake, replete with it's homoerotic male-on-male dance partnerings and darker than dark plot.  Truly, this version will not be for everyone...but, then again, neither is ignorance and bigotry.  5 Stars! Buy it, and enjoy!
summary: Southern Baptist Alert: Controversial, Yet Highly Entertaining!

reviewText: Not what I was expecting. I had read a review of Bourne's production in The New Yorker, so I knew it was an all-male cast, with the Prince falling in love with a male Swan Prince (Odette/Odile). However, I anticipated a classical production a la the Bolshoi. This is neither that, nor is it Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo (also well worth seeing). Instead, the program begins with a series of increasingly comic set pieces - the little boy Prince is bullied by his mother, the older Prince becomes infatuated with a comically sluttish girl, much to his mother's dismay, & follows the girl to a nightclub where the dancing is a mashup of 1940s swing, 1950s jive & stylized 1960s dances like the Twist. He gets drunk, staggers out into the night & finds himself stumbling along the waterfront (not the classical lake). The (male) swans come out to dance the classic ensemble set piece, whereupon the Prince falls in love with the lead swan. Everyone familiar with Tchaikovsky's story knows what happens after that. The dancing, costumes, sets etc. are terrific. You'll need to take a few breaks - this is a lengthy (3+ hours) production, & no matter how much you love the ballet, that's a long time to sit through a video. But well worth the time for anyone who loves dance performances.

reviewText: No lover of ballet  should miss this stunning production. It's a pity that  it will not be released in 3D as it was  recently in the cinemas.Matthew Bourne is one of the  most brilliant ballet  directors  in the world today.The high price of the bluray may put people  off buying it however. There have been numerous productions of  SWAN LAKE but nothing compares with this one. It is even better than the Chinese  SWAN LAKE ACROBATICS  ballet  which  is also on dvd and worth  watching if you can get  get a copy from China.
summary: ONE OF THE VERY BEST IN BALLETS

reviewText: This is NOT the Adam Cooper version of Bourne's wonderful reinvention of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake," and, for me, that's a serious problem.  Whereas Adam Cooper exuded masculinity, I'm afraid I can't say the same about Richard Winsor in THIS version, and so, for me, it was a wasted $25+.  A few years ago I loaned out my DVD of it with Cooper, which was never returned, and so I was thrilled to see that it was coming out on Blu-ray, just assuming that it was the amazing original.  So I was startled to find when it arrived that it was a different performance with different principals, and I'm afraid I could barely get through it and probably will never watch it again. I'll likely RE-buy the stunning Adam Cooper original DVD of it -- which is the version they SHOULD have released on Blu-ray!  This new one DOES have its moments -- for example, I prefer this older Prince to the one with Cooper, but that's not why most of us buy Matthew Bourne's "Swan Lake"!  But if you've not seen the original version  (or don't care), you just might enjoy this one.  But not me, nor a few others I've corresponded with who also mistakenly bought this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The plot is different from what many viewers might find familiar, which is fine, but the choreography goes to great lengths to build the plot and wastes some fabulous dance music in the process. Sadly, most of the first half of the performance seems short on dancing and long on standing or sitting around, acting. There are two rather good numbers, and then the plot gets in the way again and confuses everything. All in all, I was disappointed.
Title: N/A
